node.title: Using Joule Heating Source to simulate heat amount (power loss) of a cable
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello everyone,
I am trying to use the JouleHeatingSource to Calculate the heat source term corresponding to electrostatic Joule heating for an underground power cable. The given example Inputfile on the Moose-website runs with a given voltage value (BC) for the left and right boundary of a simple 2d copperplate geometry.
(https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/JouleHeatingSource.html)
In general:
Is it possible to use a given current value instead of a voltage value for the elec variable, to calculate the heat source term?
What is the output unit of the Joule Heating Source or the variable elec --> I assumed [W] ???
I tried applying the example Inputfile on to my cable geometry (simple 2D circle, generated with Gmsh) where I defined a physical point as a point-source (e.g. 0.1 V) and an outer boundary circle with 0 V. The material properties are assigned to the created surface, see mesh & Inputfile below. (Pleas let me know if the Link doesn't work.)
https://github.com/AgentKTU/JH-Power-cable.git
Using this approach I get a calculated temperature of 700 K at the outer boundary, that doesn't seem realistic.
I tried saving the output of the JouleHeatingSource with   save_in = var. (see AuxVariable in input file) but the results aren't reasonable. The var values are all negativ.
What is the assumed unit or value of the JouleHeatingModule???
My goal is to export the value of the Power loss (the heat source term) and implement it to my PorousFlow soil model where I added a heat source boundary.
At the end I want to simulate the temperature distribution in the soil by defining realistic boundary conditions and see how the cable temperature reacts.
I am happy about any help!
Konstantin

I tried saving the output of the JouleHeatingSource with save_in = var. (see AuxVariable in input file) but the results aren't reasonable.

Note that this option gave you the contribution to the residual of that kernel. This can be a little obscure.
They are negative because all terms get moved to the left hand side of the equation, so "sources" are negative, while losses are positive

Is it possible to use a given current value instead of a voltage value for the elec variable, to calculate the heat source term?

@cticenhour can we do this?

What is the output unit of the Joule Heating Source or the variable elec --> I assumed [W] ???

if the mesh and all quantities are in SI units, then the units of the variables and any input to the kernel should also be in SI units

Not as-designed with the JouleHeatingSource object as it is, as we make an assumption that the current $\mathbf{J} = \sigma \cdot \mathbf{E}$, where $\sigma$ is the electrical conductivity and $\mathbf{E}$ is the electrostatic electric field, which can be defined as $\mathbf{E} = - \nabla \phi$ where $\phi$ is the electrostatic potential. So, the heat source $q$ that we're adding to the PDE using JouleHeatingSource is:
$q = \mathbf{J} \cdot \mathbf{E} = \sigma \cdot \mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{E} = \sigma \cdot \nabla \phi \cdot \nabla \phi$
with standard SI units of Watts per meters-cubed. The variable elec used in the object would normally be in units of Volts. We don't make explicit assumptions on units in many MOOSE objects, so as long as you are consistent in your input file, we don't impose a specific unit system on you.
To go back to the question of whether we can use a current value or not, I cannot think of an alternative off the top of my head that you could use with the right mathematical form. @GiudGiud do you have a thought on this? Maybe we're lucky, and I missed it in the EM module and the framework when I looked through just now. In any case, your residual comtribution (in computeQpResidual) for such an object would need to be something like:
-_current[_qp] * (-_grad_elec[_qp]) * _test[_i][_qp];

Where you have a new object parameter to represent your coupled current value (if a variable), or the function / material property form that you might use to compute it otherwise.

I think this makes sense. If current is the main variable you solve for, then use a variable for it. Else I would recommend using an AD material property.

In any case, your residual comtribution (in computeQpResidual) for such an object would need to be something like:

This should be all you need to create a new AD kernel tbh so you might as well do that.

node.title: Some questions about calculating time steps
node.bodyText:
Hello moose community,
I have a problem. The adaptive time interval of the compute step suddenly increases at 5000. This is my compute setting.
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  # scheme = BDF2
  # solve_type = PJFNK
  # petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type
  #                       -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overla'
  # petsc_options_value = 'asm      31       preonly
  #                        ilu      2'
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  l_tol = 1e-04
  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 15
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-03
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-03
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 20000.0
  # dt = 0.00125

  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    dt = 0.001
    growth_factor = 1.2
    optimal_iterations = 15
  []

  # [Adaptivity]
  #   interval = 2
  #   refine_fraction = 0.2
  #   coarsen_fraction = 0.3
  #   max_h_level = 4
  # []
[]

and then, Here are the time steps I monitored.
By the way, how should I output my initial condition? Below is my output, but it only outputs the data after the first time step, not the initial situation.

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
  execute_on = timestep_end
  checkpoint = true
  solution_history = true
  # [out]
  #   type = VTK
  #   file_base = Sintering_output
  #   enable = true
  #   execute_on = timestep_begin
  # []
  # [out]
  #   type = Tecplot
  #   ascii_append = true
  # []
[]
Change execute_on = timestep_end to "initial timestep_end"

In addition, I have another question to learn. I used the phase field method and these kernels in the simulation of particle sintering. If I want to see changes in particle shape, should I use the variable bnds or c?
[Variables]
  [c] # 定义颗粒浓度变量（守恒变量）
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []

  [w] # 定义总自由能的函数值变量
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []

  [PolycrystalVariables]
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [c_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    f_name = F
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    variable = c
    coupled_variables = 'eta0 eta1'
    w = w
  []

  [w_res]
    type = SplitCHWRes
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
  []

  [time]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    v = c
    variable = w
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [bnds]
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [bnds]
    type = BndsCalcAux
    v = 'eta0 eta1'
    variable = bnds
    var_name_base = eta
    op_num = 2
  []
[]

The time stepping behavior is expected. That s what the IterativeDtTimestepper does
If you want a different time stepping behavior, pick another one in the Executioner/TimeStepper block
However, this time step, from less than one instant to thousands, is not normal?

Should be gradual. I ll check this out.
I d still change the TimeStepper if you don't want it to change
Thank you for your help in checking. I wonder if this phenomenon is normal. Also, is there any way I can limit his maximum time step?
Yes you can set dtmax and you can set multiple timesteppers in the TimeSteppers block (notice the s) and the smallest step there by any of the steppers limits the step

I set the maximum time step as you suggested, but something seems to be wrong
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  # scheme = BDF2
  # solve_type = PJFNK
  # petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type
  #                       -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overla'
  # petsc_options_value = 'asm      31       preonly
  #                        ilu      2'
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  l_tol = 1e-04
  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 15
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-03
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-03
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 20000.0
  # dt = 0.00125

  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    cutback_factor = 0.8
    dt = 0.00001
    growth_factor = 1.5
    optimal_iterations = 10
    iteration_window = 5
    dtmax = 1.0
  []

  # [Adaptivity]
  #   interval = 2
  #   refine_fraction = 0.2
  #   coarsen_fraction = 0.3
  #   max_h_level = 4
  # []
[]

error：
*** ERROR ***
/mnt/d/projects/moose/modules/combined/sintering_datas/02_04_06/peacock_run_exe_tmp_MySintering02_04.i:485.5: unused parameter 'Executioner/TimeStepper/dtmax'

There seems to be no maximum time step in adaptive step size, and I looked in the manual and couldn't find it.
you'll have to use two timesteppers to do this then.

node.title: BreakMeshByBlockGenerator: how to split inner node among subdomains?
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am trying to use BreakMeshByBlockGenerator.
I have four blocks which are included in the domain. See picture.
If I call the BreakMeshByBlockGenerator the mid node is not split, which I understand from how it implemented.
Is there a way to also split that node?

Thank you

hello
yes you can join up two domains at the top or bottom, then split. (using a RenameBlockGenerator before the BreakMeshBYBlock)
Then split that domain again (using a ParsedSubdomainGenerator for example)

Many thanks for your answer.
Actually, this is what I tried
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    nx = 8
    ny = 8
    dim = 2
  []
  [block1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0.25 0.25 0.0'
    top_right =   '0.75  0.5  0.0'
    input = gen
  []
  [block2]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 2
    bottom_left = '0.25 0.5 0.0'
    top_right =   '0.75 0.75  0.0'
    input = block1
  []
  [breakmesh]
    input = block2
    type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
    block_pairs = '1 2'
    split_interface = true
    #add_interface_on_two_sides = true
  []
  [block3]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 3
    bottom_left = '0.25 0.25 0.0'
    top_right =   '0.5 0.75  0.0'
    input = breakmesh
  []
  [block4]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 4
    bottom_left = '0.5 0.25 0.0'
    top_right =   '0.75 0.75  0.0'
    input = block3
  []
  [breakmesh2]
    input = block4
    type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
    block_pairs = '3 4'
    split_interface = true
    #add_interface_on_two_sides = true
  []
[]

but unfortunately after I rename the blocks, information of adjacent elements is lost and I cannot apply interface kernels.
Is there a way not to lose it?

I cannot apply interface kernels.

If you use the BreakMeshByBLock you cannot use interface kernels anymore. Interface kernels require a contiguous mesh. Breaking the mesh at boundaries is used for mortar / contact approaches
Are you just trying to get the interfaces added to the mesh? If so, you just need to use this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator.html

I understand. I am trying to apply interface kernels to a jump operator between a broken mesh.
I would need duplicated nodes in the mesh and discontinuous basis functions. Is there a way to do this in moose?

Hello
We do support discontinuous galerkin.
Do you really need the mesh to be broken? If it is going to be broken, InterfaceKernel is the wrong system to look at
We can do DG with a contiguous mesh, and without duplicating the nodes. The nodal values can be different on each element

I would need the same structure of DG but just along some interfaces. I would need the interface integrals over \gamma in the formula at the beginning of page 19 of https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.00443 .
Actually breaking the mesh and using interface kernels was a perfect combination.
How would you suggest to do it?

In how many places do you need to do this?
If not too many I would recommend using two variables, a non broken mesh and an interface kernel. Having two variables makes it easy to have a discontinuity

Ideally, we would like to go for 100  interfaces.
The approach with two variables is doable if the interface cuts the whole domain, but I do not know if it is possible if the interface is included in the domain, as in the picture I posted above.
Maybe I can try with constraints?
However, I think the feature I need could be of interest also for someone else.
What is BreakBoundaryOnSubdomainGenerator doing?
Many thanks

Are they ordered very regularly (like all aligned in 1D so you could alternate just two sets of variables) ?
Or is it somewhat random?

but I do not know if it is possible if the interface is included in the domain, as in the picture I posted above.

It is possible to block restrict in parts of the mesh, even if it's an inclusion and not spanning the entire domain.

Maybe I can try with constraints?

Mortar constraints are definitely a solution here. If you split the domain (e.g. use the BreakXYZMeshGenerator, that creates a non-conformal mesh)

What is BreakBoundaryOnSubdomainGenerator doing?

It does what the BreakMeshByBlock does but only along a given boundary, and creating different breakages (the breaks have non-broken nodes at each end) for each subdomain along that boundary

node.title: How to nucleate at grain boundaries instead of random locations
node.bodyText:
Hi moose community,
I am trying to simulate static recrystallization.
I am trying to follow the https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Nucleation/DiscreteNucleation.html instructions below:
"Direct order parameter modification
...
I want to know how to control nucleation at grain boundaries rather than random locations

I think you'll want to modify DiscreteNucleation. You can create a new object called GrainBoundaryDiscreteNucleation.
The first step there will be to detect grain boundaries, which you can do by analyzing the order parameters

node.title: Spatial initial condition from file
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi,
I was wondering if there is a way of specifying the initial distribution of a variable based on grid data. Say the data is available on a grid from a csv file like this (as a function of space; but it's not an expression function, it more like data collected from measurement):
x, y, z, temperature
0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 5.0
10.0, 0.0, 0.0, 4.0
10.0, 10.0, 0.0, 3.0
0.0, 10.0, 0.0, 6.0

and if it can interpolate on the nodes like a scattered interpolant?
I searched the functions for a function that reads from a file to use a Function IC (something like a ParsedFileFunction). but I didn't find one.
Or if there is a way to specify on the mesh (in the mesh module)
I would appreciate it if you could guide me with this.
This is a sample input file I was trying to modify for this:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 5
  ny = 5
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 10
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 10
[]

[Variables]
  [temperature]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = temperature
  []
  [timederiv]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = temperature
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [bottomofthesample]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temperature
    boundary = bottom
    value = 1
  []
  
  [topofthesample]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temperature
    boundary = top
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 100
  dt = 1
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
If the grid is regular the Piecewise(Multi)Constant Piecewise(Multi)Linear functions can read it, and the FunctionIC can be used:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMultiConstant.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMultiLinear.html
then this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/ics/FunctionIC.html
If not, use a PropertyReadFile user object to read the file (using the "voronoi" mode), then a PiecewiseConstantFromCSV function and a FunctionIC
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/PropertyReadFile.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseConstantFromCSV.html

node.title: WASP not available error
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am a novice to MOOSE and have been working through various tutorials. I successfully completed Steps 1 - 4 of the Tutorial 1 App Development available on MOOSE's website. Today as I was working on Step 5, I kept getting an error when I tried to compile with make -j 4.
I kept getting an error about the system not knowing WASP and lib mesh.
After getting this error multiple times I attempted to erase my MOOSE directory from my laptop, uninstall MOOSE, and re-install it. That has not fixed the problem- I am now getting the following error message
projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/contrib/wasp/install/lib: No such file or directory
Not compiling MOOSE with NEML2 because NEML2_DIR is not a valid NEML2 checkout and/or libtorch is not enabled.
ERROR
WASP does not seem to be available.
Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory,
or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install
make: *** [wasp_submodule_status] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
Any suggestions on how to approach?

Hello
Did you use the conda based installation method?
If so, did you remember to activate the moose environment before compiling? You need to do that every time, or just put the command conda activate moose in your .bashrc file
Guillaume

Hello,
Thank you for your response.
Yes, I used the conda based installation method and activated the environment by running
conda activate mambaforge3/envs/moose
before compiling.

Can you activate moose, and then run the following commands:
echo $WASP_DIR $LIBMESH_DIR $MOOSE_DIR
ls $LIBMESH_DIR
ls $WASP_DIR
I want to see if they are set, and that the location they are set to is populated correctly. In the past, and I am not so sure if this behavior still exists, it was possible to be using the Conda packages, and then run update_and_rebuild_$$$$$ scripts, and that would delete the Conda package location holding these libraries.

This is what that returned:
(base) beckford@BeckforathMBPro projects % echo $WASP_DIR $LIBMESH_DIR $MOOSE_DIR
(base) beckford@BeckforathMBPro projects % ls $LIBMESH_DIR
moose
(base) beckford@BeckforathMBPro projects % ls $WASP_DIR
moose
Can you activate moose before you run those commands?

Sorry I thought MOOSE was activated but it wasn't!
(base) beckford@BeckforathMBPro ~ % conda activate mambaforge3/envs/moose
(moose) beckford@BeckforathMBPro ~ % echo $WASP_DIR $LIBMESH_DIR $MOOSE_DIR
/Users/beckford/mambaforge3/envs/moose/wasp /Users/beckford/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh
(moose) beckford@BeckforathMBPro ~ % ls $LIBMESH_DIR
Make.common	contrib		examples	lib
bin		etc		include		share
(moose) beckford@BeckforathMBPro ~ % ls $WASP_DIR
LICENSE		WASP_README.md	bin		include		lib		scripts
(moose) beckford@BeckforathMBPro ~ %
Do I just need to run conda update --all?

You probably do not need to perform an update. You just need to return to what you were doing before :)
If you happen to have performed any git fetch or git pull commands recently, then yes, you should also perform conda update --all while the moose environment is activated (so as to update that environment).
What do you mean I need to return to what I was doing before?
Try to make moose again and see if the situation improved

It has not
(moose) beckford@BeckforathMBPro step01_diffusion % make -j4
Not compiling MOOSE with NEML2 because NEML2_DIR is not a valid NEML2 checkout and/or libtorch is not enabled.
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/mesh_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/fvics_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/auxkernels_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/kernels_Unity.C...
In file included from /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/kernels_Unity.C:2:
In file included from /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/src/kernels/ADConservativeAdvection.C:10:
In file included from /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/header_symlinks/ADConservativeAdvection.h:12:

make: *** [/Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build.mk:151: /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/fvics_Unity.x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0.opt.lo] Error 1

1 error generated.
make: *** [/Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build.mk:151: /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/mesh_Unity.x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0.opt.lo] Error 1
1 error generated.
make: *** [/Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build.mk:151: /Users/beckford/projects/moose/tutorials/darcy_thermo_mech/../..//framework/build/unity_src/auxkernels_Unity.x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0.opt.lo] Error 1
(moose) beckford@BeckforathMBPro step01_diffusion %

@milljm why is it lagging? conda update moose-dev maybe instead of conda install

It might have been lagging because the instructions were not 100% followed to the letter. For example:

Since I don't use Conda for anything else, I did delete it and reinstalled miniconda.
I then was trying to follow the MOOSE installation instructions. I came upon one error that said there was no livereload channel, so I downloaded that.


We don't have anything among our documentation that says "miniconda" anymore.
livereload comes with modern moose-dev, because moose-dev installs moose-tools. And moose-tools contains livereload

My guess is that the instructions @charlotte-b8086 are not precisely the ones found at: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html

So it is actually working now (yay!), but do you recommend I uninstall MOOSE once again, maybe delete my miniconda, install just conda not miniconda, and reinstall MOOSE again? I see from running conda --info  in the MOOSE environment that the active environment location is in my miniconda3 folder, so I am not sure if that will cause future issues.
Also thank you both so much for all of your assistance. Was the original problem that my WASP/libmesh packages were not synced up so I had to make those synced? It would be good to know how to recognize this issue in the future and prevent it from happening.
In general, do you have any recommendations on how one gets better at MOOSE?

If your miniconda is working you can use it for now. If it stops working using our conda is best.

In general, do you have any recommendations on how one gets better at MOOSE?

there are tutorials. But probably just practice and reach out when you hit issues

Hello, have you solved this problem? Now I have made the same mistake as you in the process of installing moose, but I can't solve it. I hope to get your help，The following is also my problem.
WASP does not seem to be available.
Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory,
or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install

node.title: LibMambaUnsatisfiableError: Encountered problems while solving:
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.12.02=mpich
after：
Channels:

https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda-forge
Platform: linux-64
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed

LibMambaUnsatisfiableError: Encountered problems while solving:

nothing provides __glibc >=2.28,<3.0.a0 needed by c-ares-1.34.3-heb4867d_0

Could not solve for environment specs
The following package could not be installed
└─ moose-dev ==2024.12.2 mpich is not installable because it requires
└─ moose-libmesh ==2024.12.2 mpich_0, which requires
└─ moose-petsc ==3.22.1.193.0g72c1e49ee3d mpich_0, which requires
└─ moose-mpi =2024.11.13 *, which requires
└─ moose-mpi-base [==2024.11.13 mpich|==2024.11.13 openmpi], which requires
└─ c-ares ==1.34.3 heb4867d_0, which requires
└─ __glibc >=2.28,<3.0.0a0 *, which is missing on the system.
donot find resolve approach
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

Hello
Can you please paste the output of the diagnostics script in moose/scripts?
yes，thank you，I will send you the screenshot of the wrong picture

It looks like the upload did not work.
If you can copy paste instead of screenshot, it's better for searching

(base) user@user-virtual-machine:~$ conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.12.02=mpich
Channels:
 - https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
 - conda-forge
Platform: linux-64
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed

LibMambaUnsatisfiableError: Encountered problems while solving:
  - nothing provides __glibc >=2.28,<3.0.a0 needed by c-ares-1.34.3-heb4867d_0

Could not solve for environment specs
The following package could not be installed
└─  moose-dev ==2024.12.2 mpich is not installable because it requires
   └─ moose-libmesh ==2024.12.2 mpich_0, which requires
      └─ moose-petsc ==3.22.1.193.0g72c1e49ee3d mpich_0, which requires
         └─ moose-mpi =2024.11.13 *, which requires

I'm sorry. I don't know why it didn't go up. This is the content of the error, I have pasted it all down, hope it helps
            └─ moose-mpi-base [==2024.11.13 mpich|==2024.11.13 openmpi], which requires
               └─ c-ares ==1.34.3 heb4867d_0, which requires
                  └─ __glibc >=2.28,<3.0.0a0 *, which is missing on the system.

(base) user@user-virtual-machine:~$
what version of linux are you running? Seems to not be supported by our conda build

We might have had a bad set of packages that round. When I look into this a bit, it seems newly created packages (which are in the works) do not exhibit this issue.
Can you try the following?
conda create -n moose moose-dev mpich --channel https://conda.software.inl.gov/moose/pr-29104
Ref PR that fixes this issue: #29104
I am using Wmware Ubuntu system.

(base) user@user-virtual-machine:~$ conda create -n moose moose-dev mpich --channel https://conda.software.inl.gov/moose/pr-29104
Retrieving notices: done
Channels:

https://conda.software.inl.gov/moose/pr-29104
https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda-forge
Platform: linux-64
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): failed

UnavailableInvalidChannel: HTTP 403 FORBIDDEN for channel moose/pr-29104 https://conda.software.inl.gov/moose/pr-29104
The channel is not accessible or is invalid.
You will need to adjust your conda configuration to proceed.
Use conda config --show channels to view your configuration's current state,
and use conda config --show-sources to view config file locations.
Oh,still report an error,that does not seem like a good idea.Dependent libraries do not match?.I do not  know what to do.

I am not sure why you can't peruse to that location... can you click on the link? https://conda.software.inl.gov/moose/pr-29104 If you can navigate there using your web browser, but not when using terminal: $ curl https://conda.software.inl.gov/moose/pr-29104/index.html XX The Workbench Analysis Sequence Processor (WASP) was developed to...
Updated: 2024-12-18 20:16:05 +0000 - Files: 14
% Then this will indicate you are using some sort of Government/Corporate proxy preventing you access.

WASP does not seem to be available.
Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory,
or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install
I think I have installed it, the link is ready to use, the installation package is ready to download, but there are some problems when testing again, I don't know what this WASP means?The above error occurred

node.title: Measurement of memory consumption
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Dear Moose Community,
I hope this question has a simple answer, but I'm stuck anyways: I'd like to know the total memory consumption (RAM) of my MooseApp run. It does not have to be exact.
I work on a WSL / Ubuntu.
I've read PerfGraphOutput.
So I set perf_graph=true and started a simple Moose model with mpiexec -n 1:
Performance Graph:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
|                                Section                               | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
| shaleTestApp (main)                                                  |     1 |      0.008 |      0.008 |   0.00 |       5 |    168.030 |    168.030 | 100.00 |     291 |
|   Action::SetupMeshAction::Mesh::SetupMeshAction::act::setup_mesh    |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   Action::SetupMeshAction::Mesh::SetupMeshAction::act::set_mesh_base |     2 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   MeshGeneratorSystem::createMeshGeneratorOrder                      |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                      |     2 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                      |     3 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   FEProblem::outputStep                                              |    12 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.528 |      0.044 |   0.31 |      12 |
|   Transient::PicardSolve                                             |    11 |      0.009 |      0.001 |   0.01 |       0 |    166.536 |     15.140 |  99.11 |     116 |
|     FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                    |    88 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::outputStep                                            |    33 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::solve                                                 |    11 |     70.019 |      6.365 |  41.67 |      88 |    164.479 |     14.953 |  97.89 |     116 |
|       FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                  |    84 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|       FEProblem::computeResidualInternal                             |    94 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |     32.874 |      0.350 |  19.56 |       0 |
|         FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                |   188 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|       FEProblem::computeJacobianInternal                             |    31 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |     61.572 |      1.986 |  36.64 |      28 |
|         FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                |    62 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   Transient::final                                                   |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                    |     2 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::outputStep                                            |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Finished Executing                                                                       [167.78 s] [  438 MB]

Now the same for mpiexec -n 5
Performance Graph:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
|                                Section                               | Calls |   Self(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |  Total(s)  |   Avg(s)   |    %   | Mem(MB) |
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
| shaleTestApp (main)                                                  |     1 |      0.008 |      0.008 |   0.02 |       3 |     45.483 |     45.483 | 100.00 |     106 |
|   Action::SetupMeshAction::Mesh::SetupMeshAction::act::setup_mesh    |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   Action::SetupMeshAction::Mesh::SetupMeshAction::act::set_mesh_base |     2 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   MeshGeneratorSystem::createMeshGeneratorOrder                      |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                      |     2 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                      |     3 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   FEProblem::outputStep                                              |    12 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.333 |      0.028 |   0.73 |      22 |
|   Transient::PicardSolve                                             |    11 |      0.006 |      0.001 |   0.01 |       0 |     44.707 |      4.064 |  98.29 |       6 |
|     FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                    |    88 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::outputStep                                            |    33 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::solve                                                 |    11 |     23.389 |      2.126 |  51.42 |      -4 |     44.255 |      4.023 |  97.30 |       6 |
|       FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                  |    84 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|       FEProblem::computeResidualInternal                             |    91 |      0.002 |      0.000 |   0.01 |       0 |      6.888 |      0.076 |  15.14 |       0 |
|         FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                |   182 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|       FEProblem::computeJacobianInternal                             |    31 |      0.001 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |     13.970 |      0.451 |  30.72 |      10 |
|         FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                |    62 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|   Transient::final                                                   |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::computeUserObjects                                    |     2 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
|     FEProblem::outputStep                                            |     1 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |      0.000 |      0.000 |   0.00 |       0 |
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Finished Executing                                                                       [ 45.28 s] [  249 MB]

The run with 1 CPU took longer than with 5 CPUs. And the factor in wall-time is reasonable considering I only have 32980 DOF in my non-linear system and 5 CPUs is probably a bit much. So far so good.
But the numbers on memory-consumption is not clear to me:

with 1 CPU Moose writes below the performance graph "438 MB" - in the performance graph "291 MB" is written
with 5 CPUs Moose writes below the performance graph "249 MB" - in the performance graph "106 MB" is written

More in detail:

Why does the memory consumption given in the performance graph and below is off by factor 1.5, 2.3?
Why is the memory consumption with 5 CPUs smaller than with 1? Is the memory consumption written per CPU and I have to multiply by the number of CPUs used?

Thank you in advance!

I've wanted to get back to making one of my very first projects with MOOSE, work again with Python 3.x
This DOES NOT WORK, but the following script:
moose/scripts/memory_logger.py

is designed to do what it is you are asking. It needs SERIOUS TLC. Being one of my first Python projects :(
Embarrassing to look at.

Thank you very much for this tip!
For later reference: the description for this script can be found here:
mooseframework.inl.gov/python/memory_logger.html
Oh this shouldn't be the answer... The script won't work as is... I am looking at now. I'll get back to you if this turns out to be something simple.
Ok, so let's postpone marking this as answer. I have to install PBS first before to be able to have a look. Thanks for your help!

No need for PBS if you are not operating on an HPC cluster. This script will run fine on a single machine :)
also some good news: I am already able to make this script spit back some information. So it would seem little may be required to bring this back to life.

Oh, my fault. I misread the error message I got:
  File "/home/mjg/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py", line 185
    print 'I could not find your PBS_NODEFILE. Is PBS loaded?'
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
SyntaxError: Missing parentheses in call to 'print'. Did you mean print(...)?

iirc you can just use "time" on linux to measure memory. the one from /usr/bin/time
https://stackoverflow.com/a/33532736
mileage may vary with MPI, I dont remember using it for that, but you could most likely do mpiexec -n 4 /usr/bin/time your_app-opt .... then do the sum yourself

My first test was not successful:  time --verbose ls gives
--verbose: command not found
I'll have a closer look. Thanks for the tip!
BTW: which time gives
/usr/bin/time
not sure you need verbose?
ok you do on macos when using gnu-time.

Turns out, in Ubuntu one has to explicitly use the time in /usr/bin/time to get the --verbose. This can be done using one the following ways:

calling time via its full path /usr/bin/time -v ...  (@GiudGiud already had this command, but I overlooked)
enforce the time given by which time by just prefixing an backslash \time -v ...

Doing so, gives the following numbers (all in MB, just one run each, numbers vary slightly from run to run - take with grain of salt)



Measurement method
N = 1
N = 5




Performance Graph
290
138


Finished Executing
435
283


sum of "mpiexec -n N \time -f '%M' ...."
665
1 669


WRONG, but just for fun: "\time -f '%M' mpiexec -n N ..."
664
357



As already stated by @GiudGiud, \time must be inside the mpiexec-call and one has to sum up the results. Problem here is, that all of the time-commands finish at the same time and their values tend to mix up (especially if one uses -v; -f '%M' limits this effect).
Let's see how these numbers match with the script kindly provided by @milljm

Problem here is, that all of the time-commands finish at the same time and their values tend to mix up (especially if one uses -v; -f '%M' limits this effect).

Yes that's a problem. You'll want to do something like:
mpirun -n 4 /usr/bin/time -v app-opt -i input.i &> log_${OMPI_COMM_WORLD_RANK}

(with openmpi, there are different variables for others, find out which with mpirun -n 1 env)
Then you can do the sum from the files.
But Jason's script will do what you need so no need to sink too much time into this

Ok, this is very unorthodox, supplying a patch during a Discussion. But I feel this will at least "get you going for now", while I polish it up. You'll have to do precisely the following:
Download the patch file (attached), and save it to the root of your MOOSE repository. Apply the patch like so:
cd ~/projects/moose
patch -p1 < memory_logger.patch
Next, run the memory_logger as so, on a test file, just to see if it works (replace YOU with your actual user name):
cd ~/projects/moose/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion
~/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py --run 'mpiexec -n 5 /home/YOU/projects/moose/test/moose_test-opt -i /home/YOU/projects/moose/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion/simple_diffusion.i -r 5'
Then do what the program explains to do when it finishes. If this works, we can then concentrate on how to run this on your actual problem. It should ask you to do something like the following:
~/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py --read /home/YOU/projects/moose/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion/memory.log
Note: pay carful attention to the command line arguments after --run. You need to supply absolute paths to everything. No relative paths (no use of ~/ or $HOME etc.
memory_logger.patch
May I ask if you also see roughly "1,078,340 K" for the simple_diffusion test?

Can memory_logger.py distinguish between those?

I would think only the perf graph can do that.

May I ask if you also see roughly "1,078,340 K" for the simple_diffusion test?

Maximum resident set size (kbytes): 87456

So I'm quite below that number. Is this the number with more processes?

So I'm quite below that number. Is this the number with more processes?

As requested here this is the number I got with
~/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py --run 'mpiexec -n 5 /home/YOU/projects/moose/test/moose_test-opt -i /home/YOU/projects/moose/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion/simple_diffusion.i -r 5'

I repeated the test just now. I'm getting:

mpiexec -n 5 --> MAX memory used: ( 1,074,284 K )
mpiexec -n 1 --> MAX memory used: ( 326,272 K )
(no mpiexec) --> MAX memory used: ( 332,452 K )

So even when calling without mpiexec, the max memory I get is factor ~3.8 larger than the value you get.
Can this be an effect of the WSL-Ubuntu I use?

May I ask if you also see roughly "1,078,340 K" for the simple_diffusion test?

My result:
Date Stamp                 Memory Usage | Percent of MAX memory used: ( 1,098,804 K )

Note: this is because I specifically asked MOOSE to use a refinement level of 5 (-r 5) which is very memory expensive. I did this because simple_diffusion without it, is very cheap! In fact it is so cheap, it broke (the program exited before a sample was taken):
$ /data/milljm/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py --read memory.log 
Date Stamp                 Memory Usage | Percent of MAX memory used: ( 0 K )
<trimmed>
decimal.DivisionByZero: [<class 'decimal.DivisionByZero'>]

I am sorry I did not explain the reason for adding -r 5 to the example I started with. I imagine this is why you ended up ctl-cing the script. Please drop the use of that argument and give it another go :)

Without -r 5 and without mpiexec I do not get any reading (too fast). memory_logger.py --read gives
Date Stamp                 Memory Usage | Percent of MAX memory used: ( 0 K )
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/mjg/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py", line 1165, in <module>
    ReadLog(args)
  File "/home/mjg/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py", line 946, in __init__
    self.printHistory()
  File "/home/mjg/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py", line 977, in printHistory
    tmp_str = self.formatText(largest_memory, item[0], item[1], item[5], item[2], item[3], item[4], RESET, terminal_width)
              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/mjg/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py", line 1001, in formatText
    max_length = decimal.Decimal(terminal_width - header) / largest_memory
                 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
decimal.DivisionByZero: [<class 'decimal.DivisionByZero'>]

@GiudGiud could you please repeat with -r 5?
But my model runs much longer (1 CPU: ~3 min; 5 CPU: ~45sec) and I get readings. Oh, and for my model, I never used -r 5. The script does just not stop.

hmm. Well the method I use to find the binary we are trying to track is thusly:
    # Determine the command we are going to track
    # A few things are happening here; first we strip off any MPI commands
    # we then loop through the remaining items until we find a matching path
    # exp:  mpiexec -n 12 ../../../moose_test-opt -i simple_diffusion.i -r 6
    # would first strip off mpiexec, check for the presence of -n in our
    # current directory, then 12, then ../../../moose_test-opt   <- found. It would
    # stop and return the base name (moose_test-opt).

A crude way. I was young...
Is the name of your application perhaps something generic? Perhaps the script is finding other unrelated binaries still running?

I hope not. This is the MooseApp-name and command I use:
~/projects/moose/scripts/memory_logger.py --run 'mpiexec -n 1 /home/mjg/projects/shale/shale-opt -i /home/mjg/projects/shale/models/porous_flow_block/porous_flow_block.i' 

BTW, this is the model I try to measure the memory for: in ex1 its ex1-PJFNK.i

Please allow me to add: Beside Moose, I also used another FE-Software for "my" model and checked wall time and memory consumption:
Moose (as already shown above; repeated for convenience)



Measurement method
N = 1
N = 5




Performance Graph
290
138


Finished Executing
435
283


sum of "mpiexec -n N \time -f '%M' ...."
665
1 669


memory_logger.py
1910
2916



The "other FE Software":

node.title: compile error
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I created the moose environment in ubuntu18.04, and then I cloned a moose from github, but I encountered the following compilation error.（https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git）

(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

Hello
your moose version is not in sync with your libmesh verison. You'll need to update libmesh.
Are you using conda?
Yes, I used conda, what command do I need to run next

conda update --all
then check that the version of moose-libmesh is from December using conda list | grep moose
I have run the command you provided, it seems that it must be updated, what command do I need to run next?
I'd delete the conda environment and try again (re-install). Seems the version is frozen to 4 months ago
I followed your advice. I removed the moose environment, but encountered the following problem when reinstalling the moose environment

Thank you for your reply. In fact, I still want to know how to install the latest moose on ubuntu18. Because I may need to use moose for a long time, after all, it is a very powerful, very friendly open source library.
Hello, if I need to use it now, how do I clone a moose that matches the July version? I have now reinstalled the moose environment, the specific version is as follows.
You can use git log with a date argument to get the list of moose commits from that time. Then pick a merge commit

Thanks for your reply, please forgive me for not being familiar with some of github's usage. Can you give me a line of code like this (git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git) to execute? I now have one of the moose environments in the above picture.

node.title: Unable to Successfully Close Material Property Setting in Specific Time Period
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello! I have utilized the timeperiod functionality within the control module to dynamically set the material properties within a certain block. Specifically, I aim for the same material within the same block to have three different property values across three distinct time periods. Therefore, I have configured each timeperiod to enable the corresponding material property while attempting to disable the other two.
However, during actual simulation runs, I have observed that one of the material properties remains consistently enabled. Even when I explicitly specify to disable it within a certain timeperiod, it stays enabled.
When I try to close mat5， mat5 still can't close

period0 is disabling mat5 and mat 1 at t=0.02
but at the same time, period1_2 is enabling mat5 back.

Thanks for your reply, I changed the input file slightly so that mat1 material is still used at the last time step, but I still can't understand why mat4 and mat5 always change in sync. What I didn't expect was that mat4 and mat5 were always enabled between 0 and 0.4s, and correctly disabled after 0.4s. The output at the last time step of 0.5s before I change the input file shows mat4 and mat5 enabled, and mat1 disabled, which is the same as the material enabled at time 0 to 0.4s. Is this caused by my period0 and period1_2 not working and mat5 being strangely set to turn on by default? Looking forward to your reply, thank you.

What I didn't expect was that mat4 and mat5 were always enabled between 0 and 0.4s, and correctly disabled after 0.4

Do you have a log showing this? This is not what I expect from the snippet
Note that should copy paste the input snippets rather than paste screenshots.

testtimeperiod.zip
I followed https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/controls/time_periods/materials/material.i and wrote the above file according to my problem for testing, and found that the same problem occurred in  this problem, is there something wrong with the way I write the input file or is it due to other reasons? The details of the output are as follows：
testtimeperiod.zip
Can you please use a public git repo instead of a zip file?

I'm sorry I'm not very good at using GitHub, which has caused you inconvenience. Just now, I did a simple test based on a situation similar to my problem according to https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/controls/time_periods/materials/material.i. My input file and results are as follows: https://github.com/ggb074113/timeperiod_test-3times_matChange.git

no worries.
Sorry for the delay, I was traveling
you need to add   reverse_on_false = false to each TimePeriod. This makes sure they dont all "act" outside of the exact times they turn on/off
